titleStmt.title: What would it bring you
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Whitman probably drafted this manuscript in the early 1850s as he was composing the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. Although these lines do not appear in the versions of the poems included in that edition, the numbering, paper, and ink are similar to other manuscripts with lines used in the first poem in that edition, eventually titled "Song of Myself."

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Holograph memoranda and notes, unsigned and undated, written on 27 scraps of paper
bibl.orgName: The Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature, New York Public Library
bibl.note: A draft line of poetry written on the back of this manuscript may relate to the poem eventually titled "Song of Myself."
Transcribed from digital images of the original.

revisionDesc.change: adjusted wording of work and date notes

lg.l:
What would it do bring you to be elected and take
your place in the Capitol?

I elect you to understand yourself; that is what
all the offices in the republic could not do
